identificationModule.briefTitle: Efficacy Basics of Bihemispheric Motorcortex Stimulation After Stroke
identificationModule.officialTitle: Efficacy Basics of Bihemispheric Motorcortex Stimulation After Stroke

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The aim of the study is to investigate whether the combination of bihemispheric ("dual") transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) and motor training on 5 consecutive days facilitates motor recovery in chronic stroke. Results will be compared to a matched group of patients undergoing anodal tDCS as well as a control group receiving sham tDCS. Functional and structural magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) before/after the intervention and during a 3 month follow-up will help investigating neural correlates of expected changes in motor function of the affected upper extremity.

armGroups.label: Dual tDCS + motor training
armGroups.description: Motor training of the affected upper extremity combined with dual transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS).

armGroups.label: Anodal tDCS + motor training
armGroups.description: Motor training of the affected upper extremity combined with anodal tDCS.

armGroups.label: Sham tDCS + motor training
armGroups.description: Motor training of the affected upper extremity combined with sham tDCS.

interventions.name: Motor training
interventions.description: Motor training of the affected upper extremity (5 days, 25 min/day).

primaryOutcomes.measure: Motor Function of the Affected Upper Extremity
primaryOutcomes.description: Effects of dual tDCS + training vs sham-tDCS + training on the motor function of the affected upper extremity (measured by standardized behavioral tests).
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Change from baseline after 5 days (immediately after intervention)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Motor Function of the Affected Upper Extremity
primaryOutcomes.description: Effects of dual tDCS + training vs sham-tDCS + training on the motor function of the affected upper extremity (measured by standardized behavioral tests).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Motor Function of the Affected Upper Extremity
secondaryOutcomes.description: Effects of dual tDCS + training vs anodal tDCS + training on the motor function of the affected upper extremity (measured by standardized behavioral tests).
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: After 5 days (immediately after intervention), after 3 months vs baseline (before intervention)

secondaryOutcomes.description: Effects of dual tDCS + training vs anodal tDCS + training vs sham-tDCS + training on task-specific activations and functional connectivity (measured by functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging, fMRI).
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: After 5 days (immediately after intervention), after 3 months vs baseline (before intervention)

secondaryOutcomes.description: Effects of dual tDCS + training vs anodal tDCS + training vs sham-tDCS + training on cerebral microstructure (measured by Diffusion Tensor Imaging, DTI).
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: After 5 days (immediately after intervention), after 3 months vs baseline (before intervention)

secondaryOutcomes.description: Effects of dual tDCS + training vs anodal tDCS + training vs sham tDCS + training on excitability of the primary motor cortex (measured by Motor Evoked Potentials, MEP, using Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation, TMS).

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* chronic stroke (\>6 months after stroke)
* age: 18 to 80 years
* non-hemorrhagic or hemorrhagic stroke

Exclusion Criteria:

* more than 1 stroke
* severe alcohol disease or drug abuse, severe psychiatric disease like depression or psychosis
* severe cognitive deficits
* severe untreated medical conditions
* other neurologic diseases
* severe microangiopathy
* pregnancy
